Alright, the question many are asking under the radar, but mostly no one wants to ask publicly ...
 Is Supreme Court nominee Kagan a lesbian?
 
 So Is She Gay? - The Daily Dish | By Andrew Sullivan
 
 The question everyone's whispering about Kagan
 
 I tend to agree with Sullivan here. We would not completely avoid the question of race-identity or religion in terms of how it might affect one's judicial stances, so I don't see why this issue should not be brought out in the open as well. This IS the Supreme Court we're talking about, after all.

Gay? I don't think so. But I do think she's even less experienced than Sotomayor was, and absolutely unfit for being a Supreme Court Justice.
 
 Kagan, if elected to the Supreme Court, would be no different than electing a mentally disabled janitor as governor of a state.

Don't know, don't care. The fact that she is grossly unqualified for the job is obvious. She has never been a judge, heck, she's hardly been a lawyer. She was only in practice for two years before she switched to teaching. Remember the adage "Those who can do, those who can't teach", it very much applies here.

Don't know, don't care. The fact that she is grossly unqualified for the job is obvious. She has never been a judge, heck, she's hardly been a lawyer. She was only in practice for two years before she switched to teaching. 

 
 I think it's a moral issue that's at least worth asking about, since it bears so heavily on a issue of significant controversy in our society. I do agree with you that her experience is certainly questionable.

I haven't made up my mind if she is a good nominee or not since I don't know enough. Sotomayor is kind of an embarrassment to the court so I don't have high hopes. I mean, if you are going to do a liberal at least make them a smart one. We already had O'Conner who was a fool now we have Sotomayor so if Kagan is just as bad...and lack of judicial experience doesn't help...then we are in trouble.

 You haven't sold me in the relevance of the question. The strength of a person's moral convictions will obviously color decision making in the sometimes morally ambiguous legal field, but race and sexual orientation would not seem to have any intrinsic effect on decision making.
